title: Ousted WeWork CEO and wife got rejected by multiple co-op boards while searching for Fifth Ave apt
text:
Ousted WeWork CEO Adam Neumann and his wife were reportedly rejected by multiple co-op boards while searching for a Fifth Avenue apartment because of his 'outlandish' behavior.

Neumann and his wife, Rebekah Paltrow Neumann, wanted to buy an apartment on the prestigious avenue in New York City, where units can go for as much as $50million, Page Six reported.

However, the couple was turned down by at least three buildings, with one allegedly telling their broker: '[Neumann] need not even apply.'

Neumann strongly denies the allegations and says there was never any discussion of he and his wife living in the alleged apartments.

The news comes just days after WeWork's parent company, withdrew its S-1 filing for its initial public offering (IPO) after facing scrutiny over the state of the company's finances - and a layoff of a quarter of the company's employees.

Former Wework CEO Adam Neumann and his wife Rebekah (pictured together, left and right) were allegedly searching for a Fifth Avenue apartment. They are said to have been rejected by multiple co-op boards due to Neumann's outlandish behavior

In total, three buildings are said to have rejected the couple with one saying that Neumann 'need not apply'. Pictured: Neumann attends WeWork Presents Second Annual Creator Global Finals, January 2019

'Neumann wanted the gilded life on Fifth Avenue,' an unnamed real estate insider told Page Six.

'But the brokers put in discreet calls to members of the co-op boards, and they all said: "No".'

A spokesperson for Neumann and his broker Mark Lapadius, the former head of commercial real estate for WeWork, denied the allegations to Page Six.

'This story is completely false,' the statement read.

'Mark walked into those buildings as a favor to a broker and left within five minutes. There was never any thought of the Neumanns living there, nor a discussion with anybody about them applying.'

This is not the first time that Neumann has been reported making extravagant real estate purchases.

In 2016, he bought the Linden Farm estate in Westchester for an estimated $22million and was said to be interested in a $39million Upper East Side penthouse, reported the New York Post.

Neumann stepped down as CEO of WeWork, the communal office-space company he founded, last week.

WeWork leases buildings and divides them into office spaces to sublet to members, which include small businesses, start-ups and freelancers who can't afford permanent office space.

But with location operating expenses - mostly rent - amounting to some 80 percent of revenue, it has been heavily reliant on cash infusions from its private investors.

Neumann, who has been known to buy other expensive real estate, has denied the allegations. Pictured: Neumann and Rebekah (then his girlfriend) at AnOther Magazine and Hudson Jeans Dinner in New York, September 2009

Last week, Neumann stepped down as the CEO of WeWork, which he founded, among controversy over the delay of the company's IPO

The company was initially valued at $47 billion, but Wall Street began raising questions after the company delayed a planned IPO earlier this month.

WeWork's revenue rose sharply to $1.8billion in 2018, but the company lost $1.6billion the same year.

Adding to its problems have been concerns about Neumann's behavior. He used some of his WeWork stock to secure a $500million personal loan prior to the IPO.

Anther issue? Neumann has bought properties and leased them back to WeWork, making him millions of dollars.

Page Six also reports that Neumann allegedly wanted to build a WeWork office space on Mars.

Neumann is said to have banned his employees from expensing meals to their corporate accounts if any of the dishes included meat.

He remains on the board as non-executive chairman while the CEO title has been split between two people: Artie Minson, formerly co-president and chief financial officer, and Sebastian Gunningham, formerly vice chairman.
description: Adam Neumann and his wife, Rebekah Paltrow Neumann, were reportedly rejected the co-op boards of three buildings on Fifth Avenue with one writing to their broke that Neumann 'need not apply'.
